title: Probability Greater Calorie Savings
question_text:
A national Italian restaurant has created a healthy option to one of its most popular dishes.
The original dish’s portion size has a mean $\mu$ of $1{,}500\text{ calories}$ with a standard deviation of $50\text{ calories}$, and the healthy alternative’s portion size has a mean $\mu$ of $950\text{ calories}$ with standard deviation of $25\text{ calories}$.
The resulting normal distribution of the calorie savings by choosing the healthy option over the original dish has a mean $\mu$ of $550\text{ calories}$ saved and standard deviation $\sigma$ of $55.9\text{ calories}$. John and Mary go to the restaurant, and both order the healthy option.
What is the probability that their average calorie savings is equal to or greater than $600\text{ calories}$ when John and Mary both opt for the healthier alternative?
solution:
The sampling distribution of calorie savings when we are concerned with the average for $n = 2$ becomes $\mu = 550$, which is unchanged.

$$\sigma(\text{new}) = \dfrac{\sigma(\text{old})}{\sqrt{2}} $$

$$=\dfrac{55.9}{1.414} $$

$$= 39.53$$

Now find the probability that $\bar{x} > 600$ from this distribution of sample means of size $2$.

Use the conversion formula:

$$z = \dfrac{\bar{x}-\mu}{\left(\dfrac{\sigma}{\sqrt{2}}\right)}$$

$$z = \dfrac{(600-550)}{39.53}$$

$$ = 1.26$$

Now the problem becomes finding $\text{P (z ≥ 1.26)}$.

Using the table of standard normal probabilities or a calculator, we find that the answer is $0.1038$, which rounds to $0.1$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.
